Difference is, the bar (usually) doesn't permanently ban you and pump the liquor out of your stomach the way Riot takes your account and revokes access to your skins, etc. When I pay for a product, I expect to keep that product regardless of my actions. Can you imagine if Apple (not the government) took your iPhone away if you texted people mean things. You paid for the product with the expectation that you own it forever, not that it can be revoked at any given moment.

Here's the exciting part if you read the ToA: (paraphrased) "Riot Games retains the right to revoke your access to the game at any time for any reason including but not limited to hacking,** improper conduct**, third party programs, modifying the client, etc." Its just like any other game out there. The toa is your contract. This is why you read it. It may look like an enormous chunk of text but it has a purpose. On top of that, this phrase is found on any version of their site (not the wiki, but actual Riot Games websites referring to LoL). I am prepared for downvotes.
How about the casino example; if you're caught counting cards, they'll permanently ban you and you don't get the money you gambled back.

That would be more akin to using 3rd party programs to get an advantage in the game. If you get caught, you get permabanned (just like in your casino example) and as a result, lose your rank (losing the money you won gambling). In this case, it makes sense becauseyou cheated to get that money/rank. Flaming someone isn't cheating, though (probably makes the game harder, if anything). So why would it be justified to lose the skins you paid for? You're already losing your rank, despite not cheating at the game, why should you also lose a cosmetic accessory you purchased?

To connect with the bar example, you'll also get kicked out for harassing other people; different actions, same consequence. Doesn't matter if you just walked through the casino/bar without buying a drink.

The difference is it's not a standalone, tangible object you purchased, it's basically a license to use a skin dependent on access to your account. They *could* give you the skins, but you're still not getting access to your account, so it won't matter anyways because you can't use the skins without an account.

How about this; you buy an unlimited pass to watch any movie you want at a theater, but you get banned from the theater for harassing the staff/other movie-goers. Whether or not you still have the pass (they might revoke it if it's in the contract), you're still not going to be watching any movies since you're not allowed on the premise.

How about this as an analogy. 
You buy a lifetime membership for a gym or perhaps a lifetime pass for an amusement park.
You then go and break their rules.
They ban you.
You're not getting any of that money back because you failed to follow their rules for using their facilities.

In this case though, the gym is also "resetting" all your workouts (taking back whatever you paid for). Imagine how ridiculous it would be if after a gym banned you, they forced you to gain back all the weight you lost. It just doesn't make sense. I didn't pay to rent the skin, I paid to OWN it (unless, of course, it's actually in the terms of service that you don't really own the skins/champs at all, in which case I'm stupid and should be ignored).

Riot doesn't take away any of the entertainment you got from the game. They take away the skins/champs you paid for. Much like the gym not taking away the weight you lost. Just taking away the exercise equipment and whatever other services you paid for. It's not a flawed analogy at all.

When I pay for a skin, I'm paying for the skin. That statement sounds stupid, but think about it for the second. Sure, you could argue that what I'm really paying for is the enjoyment I get for using the skin. On paper though, I am giving money to get a skin. When I pay for a gym membership, I'm really paying for the end result (healthier body). The entertainment I get from the game would be like the entertainment one would get from hanging with their bros at the gym. No one pays for a gym membership to go hang out, though (aka no one pays just for the _entertainment_ of going to the gym). Similarly, buying a skin isn't _really_ about increasing entertainment--it's a simple purchase. The concept is just counterintuitive. What other situations can you think of where something you paid for is taken back by the same company that sold you it just because you did something that they didn't like?

It's not a purchase at all, actually. It's a one-time fee to rent an item for as long as you remain a member of League of Legends. For example, where I live it's not uncommon to have gyms offer additional equipment that you can use as long as you're a member. It requires an additional fee with one of two options being available depending on the equipment type and gym in question:

1.) You pay to use the equipment in the confines of the gym. Thus allowing you more freedom to exercise without having to worry about equipment being use in a busy gym.

2.) You can take home said equipment and must return it upon giving up (or losing) your membership. You, of course; sign a sheet to help them keep track of this. (This one is rare, and usually only for free weights, to be honest)

If you read the ToS/EULA you see what I mean. They specifically say that you are not purchasing anything from them. You do not own anything on your account and they can, and will; take it back if you break their rules via temporary/permanent bans.

In this case, it's more like option 1. You aren't taking anything home. You're only able to use it within the confines of the client. And you are paying your one time fee to use those services so long as you maintain your overall membership.

You're completely right, what Riot does is laid out in the ToS/EULA and players agree to it every patch. It just seems counterintuitive (to me, at least) for any business to revoke access to a good you paid for. Judging by the downvotes though, it seems I am in the ridiculously small minority when it comes to this.

I should clarify by saying that despite losing an account with a fair amount of skins purchased, I never felt entitled to getting those skins back. I broke the ToS/EULA that I agreed to and paid the price. That's fair, but at the same time, I think the ToS/EULA itself is flawed (at least for this situation).

The problem there is this:
Without that condition in the ToS/EULA they couldn't ban people who make the game worse for everyone else.

What you're suggesting is that they allow people who harm their product, and their player base as well as their consumer base; because they paid for goods. It's not like they could let them keep their skins 'and' ban them.

It would be like someone breaking the rules of the gym. But since they rented equipment within the gym, they would be allowed back in without any penalty so long as they wrote in a different name; regaining use of all that equipment. It doesn't make any sense.

Permanent bans only happen to people who are extreme repeat offenders. So letting those offenders off-- letting them to continue to harm the enjoyment of every OTHER person who's paid for the same enjoyment they have-- is the flawed reasoning.

The options are "If you continue to treat people like garbage and ruin the game for them, we ban you and you lose all the things we've allowed you to use," or "If you continue to treat people like garbage, don't worry. We'll ban your account, but since you still have all your skins you only have to level to 30 again to continue treating them like garbage."

You do not own any skin. The individual who holds the copyright, that is who owns the skin. You need a contract for the kind of impunity that you think you get. You can buy a band's cd, but you can't play their songs with the intent of making money off of them legally. You bought the cd, you own the songs, you can do as you please with them right? Wrong, you bought a copy of the music. The band can still tell you how you can use the copy of the music you bought. Don't believe me? Read the small print on your movie and cd cases. You would have to have a contract giving you the right to manipulate said product for your own benefit before you could make calls as far as it is concerned. When you buy the cd, you are really only buying the right to listen to the cd whenever you want within the stated parameters (there are entire laws about this stuff, you should look them up). That is what you are doing when you buy a skin. You are a buying the right to play it whenever you want to. You do not own that skin in any way, shape or form. Whoever holds the copyright owns that skin. The reason your profile gets a copy of the skin when you purchase the right to use it is because if they didn't give you a copy of the skin, how would you ever use it? You still don't own it. You would need a binding contract for that specifically stating that you have shared ownership, and even then there are still some limitations.

That isn't the only way this type of business has to be conducted, though. In the Netherlands, you can make yourself copies of media that you purchase legally. So I could have that CD on any computer, phone, MP3 player, etc. that I own. The concept that you're talking about is called "space shifting", which is never addressed in Title 17 of the United States Code, which outlines U.S. copyright laws. So no, it's not explicitly illegal (or legal, for that matter) as long as you're doing it for personal use.

I am not asking for the right to copy a skin to any account I want. I'm saying that users should be allowed to transfer skins between accounts that they personally own (as that is basically what a permabanned player would be doing).

You can copy music anywhere. Assuming you mean literally copying the sound from one disc to another. However, it's still illegal to distribute these copies to your friends. Of course, Napster can tell you all about that way better than I can. So can Pirate Bay, KAT, and anyone who used broadband in the 90's.

Another one I see sometimes:

**"Riot doesn't give enough time to reform"**

They don't have to. They give you 1 or 2 warnings before they perma-ban you for treating other players like trash.  If you choose to ignore those because you have trauma in your life (ie your Dad died, your mother has cancer, you're struggling with addiction, or your girlfriend cheated on you) it still doesn't mean everyone else should be **_forced to play with you_** until you feel reformed.  Using trauma as an **_excuse_** to keep treating others like trash is a joke and nobody should have to wait for what you think is "the proper time to reform."  Either you take Riot's warnings seriously or you get to make a new account and start over.

It's like that in the work force.  If you have serious trauma in your life and you start to treat your co-workers like trash, your boss will bring you in his office.  ~~He'll offer~~ He should offer you counseling and a warning to leave your personal life at home. Your boss gets it that you might not realize how you're treating others.  So you're off with a warning at this point.  However, nobody at your work place should be treated like trash and deal with it until you feel deemed "reformed."  Eventually your boss will bring you in his office and wish you luck in your next job.  He doesn't want to say that. No boss does. They know what you're going through. But he has to send you off because everyone else doesn't have to suffer because of you.  

TL/DR: Nobody here in League should have to suffer because your are experiencing trauma in life.  If you get a warning, take it and leave your anger at home.
